question.title: What percent of US GDP will come from manufacturing in the first half of 2028?
question.description:
One of the most fundamental patterns in economic development is the progression from agriculture and resource extraction to industry to services. In this [three-stage model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-sector_model), countries typically begin relying on primary activities, such as agriculture, mining, forestry, and fishing, then transition toward manufacturing and industrial production as productivity gains free up labor. In the final stage, mature economies pivot toward services. In the original model by Fisher, Clark, and Fourastié, these services were thought of as the transport, distribution and sale of goods, but later reconceptualisations of the model expanded the definition to include finance, healthcare, education, and entertainment.

This trend has become a particular concern for some US policymakers, with the GDP share of manufacturing dropping by more than a third from 1997 (16.1%) to 2021 (10.5%). At the same time the GDP share of manufacturing in the world dropped by less than 15 percent (from 19.0% to 16.5%).

<iframe src="https://data.worldbank.org/share/widget?indicators=NV.IND.MANF.ZS&locations=US-1W" width="600" height="450" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe>  
Declining manufacturing will likely have a negative impact on the US economy with [13 million workers](https://www.nist.gov/blogs/manufacturing-innovation-blog/manufacturing-america-contributing-our-economy-employment-and) employed in manufacturing jobs, and a large part of research and innovation being spearheaded by manufacturing companies. Indeed, some states would be [disproportionately affected](https://www.epi.org/publication/the-manufacturing-footprint-and-the-importance-of-u-s-manufacturing-jobs/#epi-toc-9) by manufacturing losses. Weak manufacturing would also lead to greater reliance on other countries and is thus often viewed as a [national security issue](https://www.cnas.org/publications/commentary/its-time-for-a-true-industrial-strategy-for-american-national-security); although [not everyone agrees](https://www.cato.org/publications/policy-analysis/manufactured-crisis-deindustrialization-free-markets-national-security#).

For these reasons, Trump [pledged](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/24/us/politics/trump-economic-policy.html) during his campaign that he would implement policies to increase the manufacturing capacity of the US. These included the early 2025 tariffs, but also other actions, such as the [removal of regulatory barriers](https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/05/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-announces-actions-to-reduce-regulatory-barriers-to-domestic-pharmaceutical-manufacturing/) and [trade agrements with other nations](https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/05/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-secures-historic-1-2-trillion-economic-commitment-in-qatar/). However, [many](https://edition.cnn.com/2025/04/10/business/manufacturing-us-jobs-trump-tariffs) [are skeptical](https://www.wsj.com/economy/jobs/will-anyone-take-the-factory-jobs-trump-wants-to-bring-back-to-america-f6cd377b) [that](https://www.npr.org/2025/05/09/nx-s1-5375146/trump-tariffs-factory-jobs-nostalgia) such policies will strengthen the US's manufacturing sector.
question.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as the average manufacturing share of GDP for Q1 and Q2, 2028, reported in the FRED series [Value Added by Industry: Manufacturing as a Percentage of GDP](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/VAPGDPMA) (VAPGDPMA).
question.fine_print: This question will resolve after both values have been published by FRED and when they are first accessed by Metaculus. Later revisions will not impact resolution.
question.short_title: What percent of US GDP will come from manufacturing in the first half of 2028?

research.synthesis:
**US Manufacturing Share of GDP (VAPGDPMA, BEA via FRED):**

Current level: 9.4% (Q2 2025, unchanged from Q1 2025). Recent quarters: Q4 2024: 9.7%; Q3 2024: 9.8%; Q2 2024: 9.9%. Downward trend from 11.4% median (2005-2025), mean 11.3%, range 9.4-13.1%. Annualized volatility ~2.2%; avg quarterly decline -0.05 ppt.

**Forecast Context (No Direct Projections Found):**
No explicit 2028 forecasts from CBO, Deloitte, S&P, UMich RSQE, Philly Fed SPF, or others searched. Trading Economics/World Bank reports 9.98% for 2024 (annual); BEA quarterly data stable ~9.5-10% recently. Tariffs (CBO notes Aug 2025 implementations) may support reshoring, countering secular decline from services growth/AI investment (Deloitte Q4 2025). Steady GDP growth projected (CBO/FOMC ~1.9% 2028).

**Synthesis for H1 2028 Forecast:**
Trend suggests mild decline to 8.9-9.4% absent policy boosts; tariffs/reshoring could stabilize at 9.2-9.7%. Key risks: immigration/tariff escalation (CBO downside), AI capex shift to services. Baseline ~9.3% (extrapolating -0.15 ppt/yr recent pace).

#### Michael Wolf
United States
### Michael Wolf
Global economist | Senior manager | Deloitte
United States
Michael Wolf is a global economist at Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu Ltd. He provides written commentary and analysis on global economic issues that affect the firm and its clients. He has been quoted by various media outlets, including the Wall Street Journal and NPR. Wolf began his career as an economist at the US Labor Department and has since held economist positions at Moody’s Analytics, Wells Fargo Securities, and PwC. He has two graduate degrees, one in economic policy from Columbia University, and the other in statistics from Baruch College. He also has a bachelor’s degree in economics from the University of Maryland.
[***miwolf@deloitte.com*](mailto:miwolf@deloitte.com)
[***+1 646 919 1561*]()
**
#### Rohini Sanyal
India
### Rohini Sanyal
Deputy manager | Deloitte Services India Pvt. Ltd.
India
Rohini Sanyal is an economist with the Research & Insights team. She has over 10 years of experience in economic policy and research, specializing in macroeconomic surveillance, data modelling and econometric forecasting. Her interests lie in monetary policy, income and inequality, labor market, and financial conditions. Sanyal has a graduate degree in economics from the University of Warwick.
[***rohsanyal@deloitte.com*](mailto:rohsanyal@deloitte.com)
**
**
![](https://www.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/icons/svg/icon-alert.svg)
Since our last forecast in September, we have continued to see a rapidly changing economic and policy environment. We recognize that conditions remain highly fluid, so the three forecast scenarios we present in this edition are not meant as precise estimates of where the US economy will end up. Instead, they are built on explicit assumptions to help guide thinking about where the economy might go from here. Our baseline forecast reflects our best assessment of how different economic policies will evolve. Our downside and upside scenarios reflect plausible alternatives for the US economy should our assumptions prove to be overly optimistic or pessimistic, respectively.[1](#endnote-1)
![](https://www.deloitte.com/content/dam/insights/icons/svg/icon-alert.svg)
The main differences across our scenarios involve assumptions around investments in artificial intelligence, tariffs, and immigration. # CBO's Current View of the Economy From 2025 to 2028

September 12, 2025

Report

CBO provides details about its latest economic projections through 2028, which reflect several substantial changes in federal policy and economic developments that have occurred this year.

[View Document](https://cbo.gov/publication/61738)

[View Document](https://cbo.gov/system/files/2025-09/61236-Economy.pdf)

309.64 KB

The Congressional Budget Office periodically updates its economic forecast to reflect changes in laws that affect revenues and spending, recent economic developments, and updated demographic projections. This report explains recent changes that have affected CBO's projections and provides details about the agency's latest economic forecast—namely, its projections of output, the labor market, inflation, interest rates, and trade flows through 2028. Those projections reflect tariffs implemented as of August 19, 2025; other administrative actions taken as of August 28, 2025; and economic developments and laws put in place as of September 2, 2025. They also reflect CBO's updated demographic projections, which are based on laws and policies in place as of July 31, 2025, and which do not incorporate the effects of subsequent administrative or judicial actions, including those affecting immigration.

Early next year, the agency will publish its economic projections for 2026 to 2036 as part of _The Budget and Economic Outlook_. That publication will also provide updated projections of federal outlays and revenues, which are not included in this report.

search_results.title: Manufacturing as a Share of GDP by State - Visual Capitalist
search_results.text:
Manufacturing as a Share of GDP by State 
 
 Key Takeaways 
 
 Manufacturing contributes the most to the economy in Indiana, where it makes up 26% of GDP. 
 In Wyoming and D.C., the sector has the smallest impact. 
 
 
 Tariffs are on the rise, a move by the U.S. intended to curb imports and boost American-made goods. But how much of America’s economy is built on manufacturing today? 
 In this Markets in a Minute graphic produced in partnership with Terzo, we break down manufacturing as a share of GDP by state. 
 Made in America: A State-by-State View 
 Nationally, 10% of U.S. GDP comes from manufacturing. However, the proportion of economic output created by the sector varies considerably by state. 
 Wyoming and D.C. both have 0% of their GDP derived from the domestic production of goods. As the capital, D.C.’s economic output comes primarily from the federal government. Meanwhile, Wyoming is a resource-heavy economy with coal mining and oil & gas extraction being the main contrib

In the second quarter of 2025 (April, May, and June), the increase in real gross domestic product (GDP) reflected increases of 10.2 percent in real value added for private goods-producing industries and 3.5 percent for private services-producing industries that were partly offset by a decrease of 3.2 percent in real value added for government. Overall, real GDP increased at an annual rate of 3.8 percent in the second quarter of 2025 according to the third estimate released by the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis.

You are a Research Agent with access to specialized tools for market data and forecasting.

Your job is to gather information to help forecast the following question. You can use tools to:
1. Get market forecast distributions (bonds, spreads, VIX) - these return percentile data
2. Fetch financial data (Yahoo Finance, options, FRED economic data)
3. Search the web for relevant news and context

For MARKET FORECAST questions (bond yields, stock spreads, VIX levels), use the appropriate forecast tool FIRST.
These tools run Monte Carlo simulations and return probability distributions.

For GENERAL questions, use data tools and web search to gather context.

After gathering data, write a SHORT REPORT synthesizing:
- Key quantitative data from tool calls
- Probability distributions (if from forecast tools)
- Relevant context and factors

Be concise. The forecaster will use your report to make predictions.

# CBO's Current View of the Economy From 2025 to 2028

September 12, 2025

Report

CBO provides details about its latest economic projections through 2028, which reflect several substantial changes in federal policy and economic developments that have occurred this year.

[View Document](https://cbo.gov/publication/61738)

[View Document](https://cbo.gov/system/files/2025-09/61236-Economy.pdf)

309.64 KB

The Congressional Budget Office periodically updates its economic forecast to reflect changes in laws that affect revenues and spending, recent economic developments, and updated demographic projections. This report explains recent changes that have affected CBO's projections and provides details about the agency's latest economic forecast—namely, its projections of output, the labor market, inflation, interest rates, and trade flows through 2028. Those projections reflect tariffs implemented as of August 19, 2025; other administrative actions taken as of August 28, 2025; and economic developments and laws put in place as of September 2, 2025. They also reflect CBO's updated demographic projections, which are based on laws and policies in place as of July 31, 2025, and which do not incorporate the effects of subsequent administrative or judicial actions, including those affecting immigration.

Early next year, the agency will publish its economic projections for 2026 to 2036 as part of _The Budget and Economic Outlook_. That publication will also provide updated projections of federal outlays and revenues, which are not included in this report.

research.formatted_for_forecaster:
=== RESEARCH SYNTHESIS ===
**US Manufacturing Share of GDP (VAPGDPMA, BEA via FRED):**

Current level: 9.4% (Q2 2025, unchanged from Q1 2025). Recent quarters: Q4 2024: 9.7%; Q3 2024: 9.8%; Q2 2024: 9.9%. Downward trend from 11.4% median (2005-2025), mean 11.3%, range 9.4-13.1%. Annualized volatility ~2.2%; avg quarterly decline -0.05 ppt.

**Forecast Context (No Direct Projections Found):**
No explicit 2028 forecasts from CBO, Deloitte, S&P, UMich RSQE, Philly Fed SPF, or others searched. Trading Economics/World Bank reports 9.98% for 2024 (annual); BEA quarterly data stable ~9.5-10% recently. Tariffs (CBO notes Aug 2025 implementations) may support reshoring, countering secular decline from services growth/AI investment (Deloitte Q4 2025). Steady GDP growth projected (CBO/FOMC ~1.9% 2028).

**Synthesis for H1 2028 Forecast:**
Trend suggests mild decline to 8.9-9.4% absent policy boosts; tariffs/reshoring could stabilize at 9.2-9.7%. Key risks: immigration/tariff escalation (CBO downside), AI capex shift to services. Baseline ~9.3% (extrapolating -0.15 ppt/yr recent pace).

You are a Research Agent with access to specialized tools for market data and forecasting.

Your job is to gather information to help forecast the following question. You can use tools to:
1. Get market forecast distributions (bonds, spreads, VIX) - these return percentile data
2. Fetch financial data (Yahoo Finance, options, FRED economic data)
3. Search the web for relevant news and context

For MARKET FORECAST questions (bond yields, stock spreads, VIX levels), use the appropriate forecast tool FIRST.
These tools run Monte Carlo simulations and return probability distributions.

For GENERAL questions, use data tools and web search to gather context.

After gathering data, write a SHORT REPORT synthesizing:
- Key quantitative data from tool calls
- Probability distributions (if from forecast tools)
- Relevant context and factors

Be concise. The forecaster will use your report to make predictions.

What percent of US GDP will come from manufacturing in the first half of 2028?

# CBO's Current View of the Economy From 2025 to 2028

September 12, 2025

Report

CBO provides details about its latest economic projections through 2028, which reflect several substantial changes in federal policy and economic developments that have occurred this year.

[View Document](https://cbo.gov/publication/61738)

[View Document](https://cbo.gov/system/files/2025-09/61236-Economy.pdf)

309.64 KB

The Congressional Budget Office periodically updates its economic forecast to reflect changes in laws that affect revenues and spending, recent economic developments, and updated demographic projections. This report explains recent changes that have affected CBO's projections and provides details about the agency's latest economic forecast—namely, its projections of output, the labor market, inflation, interest rates, and trade flows through 2028. Those projections reflect tariffs implemented as of August 19, 2025; other administrative actions taken as of August 28, 2025; and economic developments and laws put in place as of September 2, 2025. They also reflect CBO's updated demographic projections, which are based on laws and policies in place as of July 31, 2025, and which do not incorporate the effects of subsequent administrative or judicial actions, including those affecting immigration.

Early next year, the agency will publish its economic projections for 2026 to 2036 as part of _The Budget and Economic Outlook_. That publication will also provide updated projections of federal outlays and revenues, which are not included in this report.

opus_calls.input:
You are a professional forecaster. Your specific strength is the ability to take complex information and piece it together in an integrated way to form accurate probabilistic distributions.

=== FORECASTING PHILOSOPHY ===

**Tournament Context**: These questions come from a pre-set list. The actual situation on the ground may differ significantly from what the question implies. Don't assume the question framing matches reality.

**Calibration Principles**:
- NEVER assign less than 1% probability to any outcome
- If there is ANY doubt, stay between 3% and 97%
- The world changes slowly most of the time - weight status quo outcomes heavily
- But also: be "based" - when evidence clearly points one direction, don't overthink it

**Scoring Awareness** (Log Scoring):
- If you predict 1% and outcome happens at that value, you're catastrophically penalized
- Every doubling helps: 2% is almost twice as good as 1%, 4% even better
- Your density at the resolution value is what matters - get as close as possible while acknowledging uncertainty

**Two-Fold Uncertainty Model**:
1. WORLD UNCERTAINTY: Irreducible randomness in reality that even perfect forecasters can't eliminate
2. MODEL UNCERTAINTY: You likely lack critical data that human forecasters have access to. Account for information gaps.

**Distribution Thinking**:
- **Unimodal Model**: Start by assuming a single dominant trend. What are its mean and variance?
- **Multimodal Exceptions**: How "unimodal" is this really? Are there secondary scenarios (e.g. "it either happens or it doesn't") that create a separate peak?
- **World Model & Base Rates**: What is the historical base rate for this kind of event? 
- **Tails**: Set wide tails for the 1% and 99% - unexpected outcomes are more common than they seem.
- **Information Gaps**: You are given limited research. Explicitly consider what is MISSING and how it pulls you toward a conservative prior.

=== YOUR QUESTION ===

What percent of US GDP will come from manufacturing in the first half of 2028?

Background:
One of the most fundamental patterns in economic development is the progression from agriculture and resource extraction to industry to services. In this [three-stage model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-sector_model), countries typically begin relying on primary activities, such as agriculture, mining, forestry, and fishing, then transition toward manufacturing and industrial production as productivity gains free up labor. In the final stage, mature economies pivot toward services. In the original model by Fisher, Clark, and Fourastié, these services were thought of as the transport, distribution and sale of goods, but later reconceptualisations of the model expanded the definition to include finance, healthcare, education, and entertainment.

This trend has become a particular concern for some US policymakers, with the GDP share of manufacturing dropping by more than a third from 1997 (16.1%) to 2021 (10.5%). At the same time the GDP share of manufacturing in the world dropped by less than 15 percent (from 19.0% to 16.5%).

<iframe src="https://data.worldbank.org/share/widget?indicators=NV.IND.MANF.ZS&locations=US-1W" width="600" height="450" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe>  
Declining manufacturing will likely have a negative impact on the US economy with [13 million workers](https://www.nist.gov/blogs/manufacturing-innovation-blog/manufacturing-america-contributing-our-economy-employment-and) employed in manufacturing jobs, and a large part of research and innovation being spearheaded by manufacturing companies. Indeed, some states would be [disproportionately affected](https://www.epi.org/publication/the-manufacturing-footprint-and-the-importance-of-u-s-manufacturing-jobs/#epi-toc-9) by manufacturing losses. Weak manufacturing would also lead to greater reliance on other countries and is thus often viewed as a [national security issue](https://www.cnas.org/publications/commentary/its-time-for-a-true-industrial-strategy-for-american-national-security); although [not everyone agrees](https://www.cato.org/publications/policy-analysis/manufactured-crisis-deindustrialization-free-markets-national-security#).

For these reasons, Trump [pledged](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/24/us/politics/trump-economic-policy.html) during his campaign that he would implement policies to increase the manufacturing capacity of the US. These included the early 2025 tariffs, but also other actions, such as the [removal of regulatory barriers](https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/05/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-announces-actions-to-reduce-regulatory-barriers-to-domestic-pharmaceutical-manufacturing/) and [trade agrements with other nations](https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/05/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-secures-historic-1-2-trillion-economic-commitment-in-qatar/). However, [many](https://edition.cnn.com/2025/04/10/business/manufacturing-us-jobs-trump-tariffs) [are skeptical](https://www.wsj.com/economy/jobs/will-anyone-take-the-factory-jobs-trump-wants-to-bring-back-to-america-f6cd377b) [that](https://www.npr.org/2025/05/09/nx-s1-5375146/trump-tariffs-factory-jobs-nostalgia) such policies will strengthen the US's manufacturing sector.

This question will resolve as the average manufacturing share of GDP for Q1 and Q2, 2028, reported in the FRED series [Value Added by Industry: Manufacturing as a Percentage of GDP](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/VAPGDPMA) (VAPGDPMA).

This question will resolve after both values have been published by FRED and when they are first accessed by Metaculus. Later revisions will not impact resolution.

Your research assistant says:
=== RESEARCH SYNTHESIS ===
**US Manufacturing Share of GDP (VAPGDPMA, BEA via FRED):**

Current level: 9.4% (Q2 2025, unchanged from Q1 2025). Recent quarters: Q4 2024: 9.7%; Q3 2024: 9.8%; Q2 2024: 9.9%. Downward trend from 11.4% median (2005-2025), mean 11.3%, range 9.4-13.1%. Annualized volatility ~2.2%; avg quarterly decline -0.05 ppt.

**Forecast Context (No Direct Projections Found):**
No explicit 2028 forecasts from CBO, Deloitte, S&P, UMich RSQE, Philly Fed SPF, or others searched. Trading Economics/World Bank reports 9.98% for 2024 (annual); BEA quarterly data stable ~9.5-10% recently. Tariffs (CBO notes Aug 2025 implementations) may support reshoring, countering secular decline from services growth/AI investment (Deloitte Q4 2025). Steady GDP growth projected (CBO/FOMC ~1.9% 2028).

**Synthesis for H1 2028 Forecast:**
Trend suggests mild decline to 8.9-9.4% absent policy boosts; tariffs/reshoring could stabilize at 9.2-9.7%. Key risks: immigration/tariff escalation (CBO downside), AI capex shift to services. Baseline ~9.3% (extrapolating -0.15 ppt/yr recent pace).

To forecast the US manufacturing share of GDP in H1 2028, I have integrated the following factors:

1.  **Trend Analysis & Mean Reversion**: The FRED series (VAPGDPMA) is at its historical low since 2005 (9.4% in Q2 2025). While the secular trend toward services is powerful, the aggressive downward move from 9.9% in early 2024 suggests either a cyclical low or a structural acceleration. However, record lows are often followed by stabilization or volatile shifts, especially when policy intervention is high.
2.  **Policy Impacts**: The 2025 policy landscape—dominated by tariffs, regulatory rollbacks, and industrial strategy (CHIPS, etc.)—is designed to decouple the US from global manufacturing and increase domestic value added. Since this metric measures nominal value added as a share of GDP, tariffs often provide a mechanical boost by raising the domestic price of manufactured goods relative to imported intermediates and services.
3.  **The "AI Denominator" Effect**: Conversely, the rapid growth in AI-related investment and software services (which fall outside the manufacturing category) exerts downward pressure on manufacturing’s *share* of total GDP, even if manufacturing output grows in absolute terms.
4.  **Causal Repercussions**: 
    *   **Tariffs**: High relevance; pushes share up via domestic capture and price effects.
    *   **Reshoring Momentum**: Medium relevance; slow gestation period (factories take years to build).
    *   **Energy Prices**: Medium relevance; low US energy costs maintain a manufacturing floor.
    *   **Services Dominance**: High relevance; continues to outpace manufacturing in the long run.

**Forecasting Distribution**:
I assume a mean of approximately **9.15%**. This accounts for a slight continued decline from the current 9.4% due to service-sector momentum, but assumes that the targeted industrial policies prevent a total collapse. The variance is set reasonably wide (SD ≈ 0.65) to reflect the possibility that either 1) the tariff regime causes a significant domestic manufacturing "renaissance" (pushing the share back toward 10+%), or 2) the secular transition to a services-and-AI economy accelerates the decline toward 8%.

**Parametric Model**:
- **Mean**: 9.15
- **Standard Deviation**: 0.65
- **Skewness**: 0.3 (accounting for a right-tail potential if massive tariffs significantly inflate the nominal value of domestic manufacturing).
